vpon your charter and your Citties freedome?
Youle aske me why I rather choose to haue
a weight of carrion flesh, then to receaue
three thousand ducats: Ile not aunswer that?
But say it is my humour, is it aunswerd?
What if my house be troubled with a Rat,
and I be pleasd to giue ten thousand ducats
to haue it baind? what, are you aunswerd yet?
Some men there are loue not a gaping pigge?
Some that are mad if they behold a Cat?
And others when the bagpipe sings ith nose,
cannot containe their vrine for affection.
Maisters of passion swayes it to the moode
of what it likes or loathes, now for your aunswer:
As there is no firme reason to be rendred
why he cannot abide a gaping pigge?
why he a harmelesse necessarie Cat?
why he a woollen bagpipe: but of force
must yeeld to such in euitable shame,
as to offend himselfe being offended:
So can I giue no reason, nor I will not,
more then a lodgd hate, and a certaine loathing
I beare Anthonio, that I follow thus
a loosing sute against him? are you aunswered?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: This is no aunswer thou vnfeeling man,
to excuse the currant of thy cruelty?

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.l: I am not bound to please thee with my answers?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Doe all men kill the things they doe not loue?

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.l: Hates any man the thing he would not kill?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Euery offence is not a hate at first?

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.l: What wouldst thou haue a serpent sting thee twice?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I pray you think you question with the Iewe,
you may as well goe stand vpon the Beach
and bid the maine flood bate his vsuall height,
well vse question with the Woolfe,
the Ewe bleake for the Lambe:
You may as well forbid the mountaine of Pines
to wag their high tops, and to make no noise
when they are fretten with the gusts of heauen:
You may as well doe any thing most hard
as seeke to soften that then which what's harder:
his Iewish hart? therefore I doe beseech you
make no moe offers, vse no farther meanes,
but will all briefe and plaine conueniencie
let me haue iudgement, and the Iewe his will?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: For thy three thousand ducats heere is sixe?

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.l: If euery ducat in sixe thousand ducats
were in sixe parts, and euery part a ducat,
I would not draw them, I would haue my bond?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: How shalt thou hope for mercy rendring none?

sp.speaker: Jewe.
sp.l: What iudgment shall I dread doing no wrong?
you haue among you many a purchast slaue,
which like your Asses, and your Dogs and Mules
you vse in abiect and in slauish parts,
because you bought them, shall I say to you,
let them be free, marry them to your heires?
why sweat they vnder burthens, let their beds
be made as soft as yours, and let their pallats
be seasond with such viands, you will aunswer
the slaues are ours, so doe I aunswer you:
The pound of flesh which I demaund of him
is deerely bought, as mine and I will haue it:
if you deny me, fie vpon your Law,
there is no force in the decrees of Venice:
I stand for iudgement, aunswer, shall I haue it?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Vpon my power I may dismisse this Court,
vnlesse Bellario a learned Doctor,
whom I haue sent for to determine this
Come heere to day?

sp.speaker: Salerio.
sp.l: My Lord, heere stayes without
a messenger with letters from the Doctor,
new come from Padua?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Bring vs the letters? call the Messenger?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Good cheere Anthonio? what man, courage yet:
The Iew shall haue my flesh, blood, bones and all,
ere thou shalt loose for me one drop of blood?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: I am a tainted weather of the flocke,
meetest for death, the weakest kind of fruite
drops earliest to the ground, and so let me;
You cannot better be imployd Bassanio,
then to liue still and write mine Epitaph?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Came you from Padua from Bellario?

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: From both? my L. Bellario greetes your grace?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Why doost thou whet thy knife so earnestly?

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.l: To cut the forfaiture from that bankrout there?

sp.speaker: Gratia.
sp.l: Not on thy soule: but on thy soule harsh Iew
thou makst thy knife keene: but no mettell can,
no, not the hangmans axe beare halfe the keenenesse
of thy sharpe enuie: can no prayers pearce thee?

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.l: No, none that thou hast wit enough to make▪

sp.speaker: Gratia.
sp.l: O be thou damnd, inexecrable dogge,
And for thy life let iustice be accusd;
Thou almost mak'st me wauer in my faith,
to hold opinion with Pythagoras,
that soules of Animalls infuse themselues
into the trunks of men: Thy currish spirit
gouernd a Woolfe, who hangd for humaine slaughter
euen from the gallowes did his fell soule fleete,
and whilest thou layest in thy vnhallowed dam;
infusd it selfe in thee: for thy desires
are woluish, bloody, staru'd, and rauenous.

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.l: Till thou canst raile the seale from off my bond,
Thou but offendst thy lungs to speake so loud:
Repaire thy wit good youth, or it will fall
to curelesse ruine. I stand heere for law.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: This letter from Bellario doth commend
a young and learned Doctor to our Court:
Where is he?

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: He attendeth here hard by
to know your aunswer whether youle admit him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: With all my hart: some three or foure of you
goe giue him curteous conduct to this place,
meane time the Court shall heare Bellarios letter.
sp.p: Your Grace shall vnderstand, that at the receit of your letter I am very sicke, but in the instant that your messenger came, in louing visitation was with me a young Doctor of Rome, his name is Balthazer: I acquainted him with the cause in controuersie between the Iew and Anthonio the Merchant, wee turnd ore many bookes together, hee is furnished with my opinion, which bettered with his owne learning, the greatnes whereof I cannot enough commend, comes with him at my importunitie, to fill vp your graces request in my stead. I beseech you let his lacke of yeeres be no impediment to let him lacke a reuerend estimation, for I neuer knew so young a body with so olde a head: I leaue him to your gracious acceptance, whose tryall shall better publish his commendation.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You heare the learnd Bellario what he writes,
and heere I take it is the doctor come.
Giue me your hand, come you from old Bellario?

sp.speaker: Portia.
sp.l: I did my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You are welcome, take your place:
are you acquainted with the difference
that holds this present question in the Court.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I am enformed throughly of the cause,
which is the Merchant here? and which the Iew?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Anthonio and old Shylocke, both stand forth.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Is your name Shylocke?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Shylocke is my name.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Of a strange nature is the sute you follow,
yet in such rule, that the Venetian law
cannot impugne you as you doe proceed.
You stand within his danger, doe you not.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I, so he sayes.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Doe you confesse the bond?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I doe.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Then must the Iew be mercifull.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: On what compulsion must I, tell me that.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: The qualitie of mercie is not straind,
it droppeth as the gentle raine from heauen
vpon the place beneath: it is twise blest,
it blesseth him that giues, and him that takes,
tis mightiest in the mightiest, it becomes
the throned Monarch better then his crowne.
His scepter showes the force of temporall power,
the attribut to awe and maiestie,
wherein doth sit the dread and feare of Kings:
but mercie is aboue this sceptred sway,
it is enthroned in the harts of Kings,
it is an attribut to God himselfe;
and earthly power doth then show likest gods
when mercie seasons iustice: therefore Jew,
though iustice be thy plea, consider this,
that in the course of iustice, none of vs
should see saluation: we doe pray for mercy,
and that same prayer, doth teach vs all to render
the deedes of mercie. I haue spoke thus much
to mittigate the iustice of thy plea,
which if thou follow, this strict Court of Venice
must needes giue sentence gainst the Merchant there.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: My deeds vpon my head, I craue the law,
the penalty and forfaite of my bond.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Is he not able to discharge the money?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Yes, heere I tender it for him in the Court,
yea, twise the summe, if that will not suffise,
I will be bound to pay it ten times ore
on forfait of my hands, my head, my hart,
if this will not suffise, it must appeare
that malice beares downe truth. And I beseech you
wrest once the law to your authoritie,
to doe a great right, doe a little wrong,
and curbe this cruell deuill of his will.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: It must not be, there is no power in Venice
can altar a decree established:
twill be recorded for a precedent,
and many an errour by the same example
will rush into the state, it cannot be.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: A Daniell come to iudgement: yea a Daniell.
O wise young Iudge how I doe honour thee.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I pray you let me looke vpon the bond.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: Heere tis most reuerend doctor, here it is.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Shylocke theres thrice thy money offred thee.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: An oath, an oath, I haue an oath in heauen,
shall I lay periurie vpon my soule?
Not not for Venice.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Why this bond is forfait,
and lawfully by this the Iew may claime
a pound of flesh, to be by him cut off
neerest the Merchants hart: be mercifull,
take thrice thy money, bid me teare the bond.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: When it is payd, according to the tenure.
It doth appeare you are a worthy iudge,
you know the law, your exposition
hath beene most sound: I charge you by the law,
whereof you are a well deseruing piller,
proceede to iudgement: by my soule I sweare,
there is no power in the tongue of man
to alter me, I stay here on my Bond,

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Most hartelie I doe beseech the Court
to giue the iudgement.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Why than thus it is,
you must prepare your bosome▪ for his knife.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: O noble Iudge, ô excellent young man.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: For the intent and purpose of the law
hath full relation to the penaltie,
which heere appeareth due vpon the bond.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Tis very true: o wise and vpright Iudge,
how much more elder art thou then thy lookes.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Therefore lay bare your bosome.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: I, his breast,
so sayes the bond, doth it not noble Iudge?
Neerest his hart, those are the very words.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: It is so, are there ballance here to weigh the flesh?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: I haue them ready.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Haue by some Surgion Shylocke on your charge,
to stop his wounds, least he doe bleede to death.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Is it so nominated in the bond?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: It is not so exprest, but what of that?
Twere good you doe so much for charitie.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: I cannot finde it, tis not in the bond.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: You Merchant, haue you any thing to say?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But little; I am armd and well prepard,
giue me your hand Bassanio, far you well,
greeue not that I am falne to this for you:
for heerein Fortune showes her selfe more kind
then is her custome: it is still her vse
to let the wretched man out-liue his wealth,
to view with hollow eye and wrinckled brow
an age of pouertie: from which lingring pennance
of such misery doth she cut me of.
Commend me to your honourable wife,
tell her the processe of Anthonios end,
say how I lou'd you, speake me faire in death:
and when the tale is told, bid her be iudge
whether Bassanio had not once a loue:
Repent but you that you shall loose your friend
and he repents not that he payes your debt.
For if the Iew doe cut but deepe enough,
Ile pay it instantly with all my hart.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Anthonio, I am married to a wife
which is as deere to me as life it selfe,
but life it selfe, my wife, and all the world,
are not with m●●●steemd aboue thy life.
I would loose all I sacrifize them all
heere to this deuill, to deliuer you.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Your wife would giue you little thankes for that
if she were by to heare you make the offer.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: I haue a wife who I protest I loue,
I would she were in heauen, so she could
intreate some power to change this currish Iew.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: Tis well you offer it behind her back,
the wish would make else an vnquiet house.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: These be the christian husbands, I haue a daughter
would any of the stocke of Barrabas
had beene her husband, rather then a Christian.
We trifle time, I pray thee pursue sentence.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: A pound of that same Merchants flesh is thine,
the Court awards it, and the law doth giue it.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Most rightfull Iudge.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: And you must cut this flesh from off his breast,
the law alowes it, and the court awards it.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Most learned Iudge, a sentence, come prepare.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Tarry a little, there is some thing else,
this bond doth giue thee heere no iote of blood,
the words expresly are a pound of flesh:
take then thy bond, take thou thy pound of flesh,
but in the cutting it, if thou doost shed
one drop of Christian blood, thy lands and goods
are by the lawes of Venice confiscate
vnto the state of Venice.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: O vpright Iudge,
Marke Iew, ô learned Iudge.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: Is that the law?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Thy selfe shalt see the Act:
for as thou vrgest iustice, be assurd
thou shalt haue iustice more then thou desirst.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: O learned iudge, mark Iew, a learned iudge.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: I take this offer then, pay the bond thrice
and let the Christian goe.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Heere is the money.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Soft, the Iew shal haue all iustice, soft no hast,
he shall haue nothing but the penalty.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: O Iew, an vpright Iudge, a learned Iudge.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Therefore prepare thee to cut of the flesh,
Shed thou no blood, nor cut thou lesse nor more
but iust a pound of flesh: if thou tak'st more
or lesse then a iust pound, be it but so much
as makes it light of heauy in the substance,
or the deuision of the twentith part
of one poore scruple, nay if the scale doe turne
but in the estimation of a hayre,
thou dyest, and all thy goods are confiscate.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: A second Daniell, a Daniell Iew,
now infidell I haue you on the hip.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Why doth the Iew pause, take thy forfaiture.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: Giue me my principall, and let me goe.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: I haue it ready for thee, here it is.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Hee hath refusd it in the open Court,
hee shall haue meerely iustice and his bond.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: A Daniell still say I, a second Daniell,
I thanke thee Iew for teaching me that word.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: Shall I not haue barely my principall?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Thou shalt haue nothing but the forfaiture
to be so taken at thy perrill Iew.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: Why then the deuill giue him good of it:
Ile stay no longer question.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Tarry Iew,
the law hath yet another hold on you.
It is enacted in the lawes of Venice,
if it be proued against an alien,
that by direct, or indirect attempts
he seeke the life of any Citizen,
the party gainst the which he doth contriue,
shall seaze one halfe his goods, the other halfe
comes to the priuie cofler of the State,
and the offenders life lies in the mercy
of the Duke onely, gainst all other voyce.
In which predicament I say thou standst:
for it appeares by manifest proceeding,
that indirectly, and directly to
thou hast contriued against the very life
of the defendant: and thou hast incurd
the danger formorly by me rehearst.
Downe therefore, and beg mercie of the Duke.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Beg that thou maist haue leaue to hang thy selfe,
and yet thy wealth beeing forfait to the state,
thou hast not left the value of a cord,
therefore thou must be hangd at the states charge.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: That thou shalt see the difference of our spirit
I pardon thee thy life before thou aske it:
for halfe thy wealth, it is Anthonios,
the other halfe comes to the generall state,
which humblenes may driue vnto a fine.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I for the state, not for Anthonio.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: Nay, take my life and all, pardon not that,
you take my house, when you doe take the prop
that doth sustaine my house: you take my life
when you doe take the meanes whereby I liue.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: What mercy can you render him Anthonio?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: A halter gratis, nothing else for Godsake.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: So please my Lord the Duke, & all the Court
to quit the fine for one halfe of his goods,
I am content: so he will let me haue
the other halfe in vse, to render it
vpon his death vnto the Gentleman
that lately stole his daughter.
Two things prouided more, that for this fauour
he presently become a Christian:
the other, that he doe record a gift
heere in the Court of all he dies possest
vnto his sonne Lorenzo and his daughter.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: He shall doe this, or else I doe recant
the pardon that I late pronounced heere.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Art thou contented Iew? what dost thou say?

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: I am content.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Clarke, draw a deede of gift.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: I pray you giue me leaue to goe from hence,
I am not well, send the deede after me,
and I will signe it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Get thee gone, but doe it.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: In christning shalt thou haue two Godfathers,
had I beene iudge, thou shouldst haue had ten more,
to bring thee to the gallowes, not to the font.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Sir I entreate you home with me to dinner.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I humbly doe desire your Grace of pardon,
I must away this night toward Padua,
and it is meete I presently set forth.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I am sorry that your leysure serues you not.
Anthonio, gratifie this gentleman,
for in my mind you are much bound to him.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Most worthy gentleman, I and my friend
haue by your wisedome been this day aquitted
of greeuous penalties, in Iewe whereof,
three thousand ducats due vnto the Iew
wee freely cope your curtious paines withall.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: And stand indebted ouer and aboue
in loue and seruice to you euer-more.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Hee is well payd that is well satisfied,
and I deliuering you, am satisfied,
and therein doe account my selfe well payd,
my minde was neuer yet more mercinarie.
I pray you know me when we meete againe,
I wish you well, and so I take my leaue.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Deere sir, of force I must attempt you further,
take some remembrance of vs as a tribute,
not as fee: graunt me two things I pray you,
not to deny me, and to pardon me.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: You presse me farre, and therefore I wil yeeld,
giue mee your gloues, Ile weare them for your sake,
and for your loue ile take this ring from you,
doe not draw back your hand, ile take no more,
and you in loue shall not denie me this?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: This ring good sir, alas it is a trifle,
I will not shame my selfe to giue you this?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I will haue nothing else but onely this,
and now me thinks I haue a minde to it?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: There's more depends on this then on the valew,
the dearest ring in Venice will I giue you,
and finde it out by proclamation,
onely for this I pray you pardon me?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I see sir you are liberall in offers,
you taught me first to beg, and now me thinks
you teach me how a begger should be aunswerd.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Good sir, this ring was giuen me by my wife,
and when she put it on, she made me vowe
that I should neither sell, nor giue, nor loose it.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: That scuse serues many men to saue their gifts,
and if your wife be not a mad woman,
and know how well I haue deseru'd this ring,
she would not hold out enemy for euer
for giuing it to me: well, peace be with you.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: My L. Bassanio, let him haue the ring,
let his deseruings and my loue withall
be valued gainst your wiues commaundement.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Goe Gratiano, runne and ouer-take him,
giue him the ring, and bring him if thou canst
vnto Anthonios house, away, make hast.
Come, you and I will thither presently,
and in the morning early will we both
flie toward Belmont, come Anthonio.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Enquire the Iewes house out, giue him this deed,
and let him signe it, weele away to night,
and be a day before our husbands home:
this deede will be well welcome to Lorenzo?

sp.speaker: Grati.
sp.l: Faire sir, you are well ore-tane:
My L. Bassanio vpon more aduice,
hath sent you heere this ring, and doth intreate
your company at dinner.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: That cannot be;
his ring I doe accept most thankfully,
and so I pray you tell him: furthermore,
I pray you shew my youth old Shylockes house.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: That will I doe.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: Sir, I would speake with you:
Ile see if I can get my husbands ring
which I did make him sweare to keepe for euer.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Thou maist I warrant, we shal haue old swearing
that they did giue the rings away to men;
but wele out-face them, and out-sweare them to:
away, make hast, thou knowst where I will tarry.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: Come good sir, will yov shew me to this house.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: The moone shines bright. In such a night as this,
when the sweet winde did gently kisse the trees,
and they did make no noyse, in such a night
Troylus me thinks mounted the Troian walls,
and sigh'd his soule toward the Grecian tents
where Cressed lay that night.

sp.speaker: Jessi.
sp.l: In such a night
did Thisbie fearefully ore-trip the dewe,
and saw the Lyons shadow ere him selfe,
and ranne dismayed away.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: In such a night
stoode Dido with a willow in her hand
vpon the wilde sea banks, and waft her Loue
to come againe to Carthage.

sp.speaker: Iessi.
sp.l: In such a night
Medea gathered the inchanted hearbs
that did renew old Eson.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: In such a night
did Iessica steale from the wealthy Iewe,
and with an vnthrift loue did runne from Venice,
as farre as Belmont.

sp.speaker: Iessi.
sp.l: In such a night
did young Lorenzo sweare he loued her well,
stealing her soule with many vowes of faith,
and nere a true one.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: In such a night
did pretty Iessica (like a little shrow)
slaunder her Loue, and he forgaue it her.

sp.speaker: Iessi.
sp.l: I would out-night you did no body come:
But harke, I heare the footing of a man.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Who comes so fast in silence of the night?

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: A friend?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: A friend, what friend, your name I pray you friend?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Stephano is my name, and I bring word
my Mistres will before the breake of day
be heere at Belmont, she doth stray about
by holy crosses where she kneeles and prayes
for happy wedlock houres.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Who comes with her?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: None but a holy Hermit and her mayd:
I pray you is my Maister yet returnd?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: He is not, nor we haue not heard from him,
But goe we in I pray thee Iessica,
and ceremoniously let vs prepare
some welcome for the Mistres of the house.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.l: Sola, sola: wo ha, ho sola, sola.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Who calls?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Sola, did you see M. Lorenzo, & M. Lorenzo sola, sola.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Leaue hollowing man, heere.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.l: Sola, where, where?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Heere?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Tell him there's a Post come from my Maister, with his horne full of good newes, my Maister will be heere ere morning sweete soule.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Let's in, and there expect their comming.
And yet no matter: why should we goe in.
My friend Stephen, signifie pray you
within the house, your mistres is at hand,
and bring your musique foorth into the ayre.
How sweet the moone-light sleepes vpon this banke,
heere will we sit, and let the sounds of musique
creepe in our eares soft stilnes, and the night
become the tutches of sweet harmonie:
sit Iessica, looke how the floore of heauen
is thick inlayed with pattens of bright gold,
there's not the smallest orbe which thou beholdst
but in his motion like an Angell sings,
still quiring to the young eyde Cherubins;
such harmonie is in immortall soules,
but whilst this muddy vesture of decay
dooth grosly close it in, we cannot heare it:
Come hoe, and wake Diana with a himne,
with sweetest tutches pearce your mistres eare,
and draw her home with musique.

sp.speaker: Iessi.
sp.l: I am neuer merry when I heare sweet musique.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: The reason is▪ your spirits are attentiue:
for doe but note a wild and wanton heard
or race of youthfull and vnhandled colts
fetching mad bounds, bellowing and neghing loude,
which is the hote condition of their blood,
if they but heare perchance a trumpet sound,
or any ayre of musique touch their eares,
you shall perceaue them make a mutuall stand,
their sauage eyes turn'd to a modest gaze,
by the sweet power of musique: therefore the Poet
did faine that Orpheus drew trees, stones, and floods.
Since naught so stockish hard and full of rage,
but musique for the time doth change his nature,
the man that hath no musique in himselfe,
nor is not moued with concord of sweet sounds,
is fit for treasons, stratagems, and spoiles,
the motions of his spirit are dull as night,
and his affections darke as Terebus:
let no such man be trusted: marke the musique.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: That light we see is burning in my hall:
how farre that little candell throwes his beames,
so shines a good deede in a naughty world.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: When the moone shone we did not see the candle?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: So dooth the greater glory dim the lesse,
a substitute shines brightly as a King
vntill a King be by, and then his state
empties it selfe, as doth an inland brooke
into the maine of waters: musique harke.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: It is your musique Madame of the house?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Nothing is good I see without respect,
me thinks it sounds much sweeter then by day?

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: Silence bestowes that vertue on it Madam?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: The Crow doth sing as sweetly as the Larke
when neither is attended: and I thinke
the Nightingale if she should sing by day
when euery Goose is cackling, would be thought
no better a Musition then the Renne?
How many things by season, seasond are
to their right prayse, and true perfection:
Peace, how the moone sleepes with Endimion,
and would not be awak'd.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: That is the voyce,
or I am much deceau'd of Portia.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: He knowes me as the blind man knowes the Cuckoe
by the bad voyce?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Deere Lady welcome home?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: We haue bin praying for our husbands welfare,
which speed we hope the better for our words:
are they return'd?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Madam, they are not yet:
but there is come a Messenger before
to signifie their comming?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Goe in Nerrissa.
Giue order to my seruants, that they take
no note at all of our being absent hence,
nor you Lorenzo, Jessica nor you.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Your husband is at hand, I heare his trumpet,
we are no tell-tales Madame, feare you not.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: This night me thinks is but the day light sicke,
it lookes a little paler, tis a day,
such as the day is when the sunne is hid.

div.stage: Enter Bassanio, Anthonio, Gratiano, and their followers.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: We should hold day with the Antipodes,
if you would walke in absence of the sunne.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Let me giue light, but let me not be light,
for a light wife doth make a heauie husband,
and neuer be Bassanio so for me,
but God sort all: you are welcome home my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: I thank you Madam, giue welcome to my friend,
this is the man, this is Anthonio,
to whom I am so infinitely bound.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: You should in all sence be much bound to him,
for as I heare he was much bound for you.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: No more then I am well acquitted of.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Sir, you are very welcome to our house:
it must appeare in other wayes then words,
therefore I scant this breathing curtesie.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: By yonder moone I sweare you doe me wrong,
infaith I gaue it to the Iudges Clarke,
would he were gelt that had it for my part,
since you doe take it Loue so much at hart.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: A quarrell hoe already, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Grati.
sp.l: About a hoope of gold, a paltry ring
that she did giue me, whose posie was
for all the world like Cutlers poetry
vpon a knife, Loue me, and leaue me not.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: What talke you of the posie or the valew:
You swore to me when I did giue you,
that you would weare it till your houre of death,
and that it should lie with you in your graue,
though not for me, yet for your vehement oathes,
you should haue beene respectiue and haue kept it.
Gaue it a Iudges Clarke: no Gods my Iudge
the Clarke will nere weare haire ons face that had it.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: He will, and if he liue to be a man.

sp.speaker: Nerrissa.
sp.l: I, if a woman liue to be a man.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Now by this hand I gaue it to a youth,
a kind of boy, a little scrubbed boy,
no higher then thy selfe, the Iudges Clarke,
a prating boy that begd it as a fee,
I could not for my hart deny it him.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: You were to blame, I must be plaine with you,
to part so slightly with your wiues first gift,
a thing stuck on with oaths vpon your finger,
and so riueted with faith vnto your flesh.
I gaue my Loue a ring, and made him sweare
neuer to part with it, and heere he stands:
I dare be sworne for him he would not leaue it,
nor pluck it from his finger, for the wealth
that the world maisters. Now in faith Gratiano
you giue your wife too vnkind a cause of griefe,
and twere to me I should be mad at it.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Why I were best to cut my left hand off,
and sweare I lost the ring defending it.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: My Lord Bassanio gaue his ring away
vnto the Iudge that begd it, and indeede
deseru'd it to? and then the boy his Clarke
that tooke some paines in writing, he begd mine,
and neither man nor maister would take ought
but the two rings.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: What ring gaue you my Lord?
Not that I hope which you receau'd of me.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: If I could add a lie vnto a fault,
I would deny it: but you see my finger
hath not the ring vpon it, it is gone.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Euen so voyd is your false hart of truth.
By heauen I will nere come in your bed
vntill I see the ring?

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: Nor I in yours
till I againe see mine?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Sweet Portia,
if you did know to whom I gaue the ring,
if you did know for whom I gaue the ring,
and would conceaue for what I gaue the ring,
and how vnwillingly I left the ring,
when naught would be accepted but the ring,
you would abate the strength of your displeasure?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: If you had knowne the vertue of the ring,
or halfe her worthines that gaue the ring,
or your owne honour to containe the ring,
you would not then haue parted with the ring:
what man is there so much vnreasonable
if you had pleasd to haue defended it
with any termes of zeale: wanted the modesty
to vrge the thing held as a ceremonie:
Nerrissa teaches me what to beleeue,
ile die for't, but some woman had the ring?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: No by my honour Madam, by my soule
no woman had it, but a ciuill Doctor,
which did refuse three thousand ducats of me,
and begd the ring, the which I did denie him,
and sufferd him to goe displeasd away,
euen he that had held vp the very life
of my deere friend. What should I say sweet Lady,
I was inforc'd to send it after him,
I was beset with shame and curtesie,
my honour would not let ingratitude
so much besmere it: pardon me good Lady,
for by these blessed candels of the night,
had you been there, I think you would haue begd
the ring of me to giue the worthy Doctor?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Let not that Doctor ere come neere my house
since he hath got the iewell that I loued,
and that which you did sweare to keepe for me,
I will become as liberall as you,
Ile not deny him any thing I haue,
no, not my body, nor my husbands bed:
Know him I shall, I am well sure of it.
Lie not a night from home. Watch me like Argos,
if you doe not, if I be left alone,
now by mine honour which is yet mine owne.
ile haue that Doctor for mine bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Nerrissa.
sp.l: And I his Clark: therefore be well aduisd
how you doe leaue me to mine owne protection.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Well doe you so: let not me take him then,
for if I doe, ile mar the young Clarks pen.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I am th'vnhappy subiect of these quarrells.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Sir, greeue not you, you are welcome notwithstanding.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Portia, forgiue me this enforced wrong,
and in the hearing of these many friends
I sweare to thee, euen by thine owne faire eyes
wherein I see my selfe.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Marke you but that?
In both my eyes he doubly sees himselfe:
In each eye one, sweare by your double selfe,
and there's an oath of credite.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Nay, but heare me.
Pardon this fault, and by my soule I sweare
I neuer more will breake an oath with thee.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I once did lend my body for his wealth,
which but for him that had your husbands ring
had quite miscaried. I dare be bound againe,
my soule vpon the forfet, that your Lord
will neuer more breake faith aduisedly.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Then you shall be his surety: giue him this,
and bid him keepe it better then the other.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Here Lord Bassanio, sweare to keepe this ring.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: By heauen it is the same I gaue the Doctor.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I had it of him: pardon me Bassanio,
for by this ring the Doctor lay with me.

sp.speaker: Nerrissa.
sp.l: And pardon me my gentle Gratiano,
for that same scrubbed boy the Doctors Clarke
in liew of this, last night did he with me.

sp.speaker: Grati.
sp.l: Why this is like the mending of high wayes
in Sommer where the wayes are faire enough?
What, are we cuckolds ere we haue deseru'd it.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Speake not so grosly, you are all amaz'd;
Heere is a letter, reade it at your leasure,
It comes from Padua from Bellario,
there you shall finde that Portia was the Doctor,
Nerrissa there her Clarke. Lorenzo heere
shall witnes I set foorth as soone as you,
and euen but now returnd: I haue not yet
enterd my house. Anthonio you are welcome,
and I haue better newes in store for you
than you exspect: vnseale this letter soone,
there you shall finde three of your Argosies
are richly come to harbour sodainly.
You shall not know by what strange accident
I chaunced on this letter.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: I am dumb?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Were you the Doctor, and I knew you not?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Were you the Clark that is to make me cuckold.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: I but the Clarke that neuer meanes to doe it,
vnlesse he liue vntill he be a man.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: (Sweet Doctor) you shall be my bedfellow,
when I am absent then lie with my wife.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: (Sweet Lady) you haue giuen me life and lyuing;
for heere I reade for certaine that my ships
are safely come to Rode.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: How now Lorenzo?
my Clarke hath some good comforts to for you.

sp.speaker: Ner
sp.l: I, and ile giue them him without a fee.
There doe I giue to you and Iessica
from the rich Iewe, a speciall deede of gift
after his death, of all he dies possest of.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Faire Ladies, you drop Manna in the way
of starued people.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: It is almost morning,
and yet I am sure you are not satisfied
of these euents at full. Let vs goe in,
and charge vs there vpon intergotories,
and we will aunswer all things faithfully.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Let it be so, the first intergory
that my Nerrissa shall be sworne on, is,
whether till the next night she had rather stay,
or goe to bed now being two houres to day:
But were the day come, I should wish it darke
till I were couching with the Doctors Clarke.
Well, while I liue, ile feare no other thing
so sore, as keeping safe Nerrissas ring.
